fields.Title of Presentation: <span style="font-size:11pt;">The impact of a health and wellness course on positive and negative affect in college students.</span>
fields.Description/Abstract:
<p style="font-weight:400;"><strong>ABSTRACT</strong></p>
<p style="font-weight:400;"><strong>Introduction:</strong><span> </span>The 2021 annual report by the Center for Collegiate Mental<span> </span><span>Health</span><span> </span>reported that of 153,233<span> </span><span>students</span><span> </span>who sought university counseling, 65.5% reported anxiety as a problem, 49.1% reported stress, and 47.2% experienced depression. Over the past twenty years,<span> </span><span>college</span><span> </span>counseling services have also experienced explosive and increasing demand and are struggling to keep up with increasing student needs. In order to help with the demand,<span> </span><span>college</span><span> </span>campuses are seeking numerous ways to help with these challenges. Of interventions studied,<span> </span><span>positive</span><span> </span>psychological approaches, mindfulness, and cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) techniques are the most impactful interventions that have demonstrated the greatest efficacy, particularly in improving<span> </span><span>negative</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>positive</span><span> </span><span>affect</span>. While most<span> </span><span>college</span><span> </span><span>health</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>wellness</span><span> </span>courses tend to focus more on physical<span> </span><span>health</span><span> </span>and show improvements on physical efficacy, it would make sense that if the same<span> </span><span>course</span>, with additional emphasis on psychological<span> </span><span>health</span><span> </span>and consistently integrating and practicing techniques like CBT, might also improve<span> </span><span>negative</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>positive</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span> </span>scores.<span> </span><strong>Purpose:<span> </span></strong>The purpose of this study is to see if two 15-week<span> </span><span>health</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>wellness</span><span> </span><span>college</span><span> </span>courses, taught concurrently from two different perspectives (e.g., traditional approach and CBT approach), will significantly reduce<span> </span><span>negative</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span> </span>and increase<span> </span><span>positive</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span> </span>in<span> </span><span>college</span>-age<span> </span><span>students</span>.<span> </span><strong>Hypothesis:<span> </span></strong>1) Both the control and experimental<span> </span><span>health</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>wellness</span><span> </span>courses will result in decreased<span> </span><span>negative</span><span> </span>trait<span> </span><span>affect</span><span> </span>and increased<span> </span><span>positive</span><span> </span>trait<span> </span><span>affect</span>.<span> </span>2) If changes in<span> </span><span>affect</span><span> </span>are significant across the 15-week semester, we will test whether improved cognitive distortion scores that occur in the experimental<span> </span><span>course</span>, act as a mediator to changes in<span> </span><span>positive</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>negative</span><span> </span><span>affect</span>.<span> </span><strong>Participants:</strong><span> </span>Male and female<span> </span><span>college</span>-age<span> </span><span>students</span><span> </span>(18-50 years), from different backgrounds and different majors, will be recruited on a volunteer basis after enrolling in one of two 15-week<span> </span><span>health</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>wellness</span><span> </span>courses (EXHS 155 at CWI and KINES 141 at BSU).<span> </span><strong>Methods:<span> </span></strong><span>Students</span><span> </span>will attend two-hours and thirty-minutes of lecture time per week for 15 weeks. Both courses will be taught face-to-face during concurrent semesters (Spring 23) by highly qualified instructors.This study is an experimental design with pre-and post-tests administered to experimental and control groups.<span> </span><span>Students</span><span> </span>will complete the demographic/<span>wellness</span><span> </span>questionnaire during the second class of the semester only; they will complete the PANAS-Gen during the second and last classes of the semester, and the CD-Quest will be completed in the second class, and every 3 weeks during the semester (weeks 2, 5, 8, 11, and 14).<span> </span><strong>Statistical Analysis:<span> </span></strong>A mixed model repeated measures ANOVA analysis will be conducted (P<span> </span><<span> </span>.05), with group assignment as the independent variable and changes in PANAS-Gen score as the dependent variable. Previous therapy may be used as a possible covariate. A mixed model repeated measures ANOVA analysis will be conducted to assess changes in cognitive distortions using the CD-Quest results. If statistically significant (p<0.005) changes are found in PANAS-Gen scores from pre-to post-intervention, a mediation linear regression analysis will be run to examine whether changes in PANAS-Gen scores were mediated by changes in cognitive behavioral strategies (CD-Quest). Statistical analysis will be conducted using SPSS V28.0.1.<span> </span><strong>Expected Outcomes:<span> </span></strong>Both<span> </span><span>health</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>wellness</span><span> </span>courses will result in improved<span> </span><span>negative</span><span> </span>and<span> </span><span>positive</span><span> </span><span>affect</span><span> </span>scores. For the experimental<span> </span><span>course</span>, reduced cognitive distortions will mediate reductions in<span> </span><span>negative</span><span> </span><span>affect</span>.</p>
